Method Detail

getCaretPosition

int getCaretPosition()
Returns the position of the text insertion caret for the text component.
A newline is only one caret position. You must handle the \r\n issue by yourself to find the correct position in your text string. 
 IInFormLongText textarea =(IInFormLongText) context.getGroup().findByName("storage_emailText_body");
 String value = textarea.getValue();
 // NOTE: A linebreak is only ONE caret position. You must handle the \r\n issue by your self.
 value = StringUtil.replace(value, "\r\n","\n");
 if(textarea.getSelectionStart()!= textarea.getSelectionEnd())
 {
   String start  = value.substring(0,textarea.getSelectionStart());
   String center = value.substring(textarea.getSelectionStart(), textarea.getSelectionEnd());
   String end    = value.substring(textarea.getSelectionEnd(), value.length());
   textarea.setValue(start+"[b]"+center+"[/b]"+end);
 }
 else
 {
   String start  = value.substring(0,textarea.getCaretPosition());
   String end    = value.substring(textarea.getCaretPosition(), value.length());
   textarea.setValue(start+"[X]"+end);
 }

Returns:
the position of the text insertion caret for the text component >= 0
Since:
2.8.5

setCaretPosition

void setCaretPosition(int caretPosition)
This method request the focus for the text element and tries to set the caret position at the hands over location.

It is important to know, that a linebreak (e.g. \r\n or \n or \r) will be counted as a single caret postion.

Parameters:
caretPosition - the new caret position
Since:
2.8.5
See Also:
IForm.setFocus(IInFormLongText, int)

getSelectionStart

int getSelectionStart()
Returns the selected text's start position. Return 0 for an empty document, or the value of getCaretPosition if no selection.

A newline is only one caret position. You must handle the \r\n issue by yourself to find the correct position in your text string. 
 IInFormLongText textarea =(IInFormLongText) context.getGroup().findByName("storage_emailText_body");
 String value = textarea.getValue();
 // NOTE: A linebreak is only ONE caret position. You must handle the \r\n issue by your self.
 value = StringUtil.replace(value, "\r\n","\n");
 if(textarea.getSelectionStart()!= textarea.getSelectionEnd())
 {
   String start  = value.substring(0,textarea.getSelectionStart());
   String center = value.substring(textarea.getSelectionStart(), textarea.getSelectionEnd());
   String end    = value.substring(textarea.getSelectionEnd(), value.length());
   textarea.setValue(start+"[b]"+center+"[/b]"+end);
 }
 else
 {
   String start  = value.substring(0,textarea.getCaretPosition());
   String end    = value.substring(textarea.getCaretPosition(), value.length());
   textarea.setValue(start+"[X]"+end);
 }

Returns:
the start position >= 0 && <=getSelectionEnd
Since:
2.8.5

getSelectionEnd

int getSelectionEnd()
Returns the selected text's end position. Return 0 for an empty document, or the value of getCaretPosition if no selection.

A newline is only one caret position. You must handle the \r\n issue by yourself to find the correct position in your text string. 
 IInFormLongText textarea =(IInFormLongText) context.getGroup().findByName("storage_emailText_body");
 String value = textarea.getValue();
 // NOTE: A linebreak is only ONE caret position. You must handle the \r\n issue by your self.
 value = StringUtil.replace(value, "\r\n","\n");
 if(textarea.getSelectionStart()!= textarea.getSelectionEnd())
 {
   String start  = value.substring(0,textarea.getSelectionStart());
   String center = value.substring(textarea.getSelectionStart(), textarea.getSelectionEnd());
   String end    = value.substring(textarea.getSelectionEnd(), value.length());
   textarea.setValue(start+"[b]"+center+"[/b]"+end);
 }
 else
 {
   String start  = value.substring(0,textarea.getCaretPosition());
   String end    = value.substring(textarea.getCaretPosition(), value.length());
   textarea.setValue(start+"[X]"+end);
 }

Returns:
the end position >= 0 && >= getSelectionStart
Since:
2.8.5

setLinkHandling

void setLinkHandling(ILinkParser parser,
                     ILinkEventListener listener)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
Sets the parser to use when parsing links. We need to parse links to transform a link reference passed as a raw string by the long text element into a clickable link object.
Use RegExprLinkParser as regualr expression link parser.

Parameters:
parser - the link parser to use
listener - the listener to use
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
Since:
2.10
See Also:
RegExprLinkParser
